results.title: Chemical reactions I
results.creator_credit: Open University, BBC-TV and Barrie Whatley
results.brief_description: Discusses the vibration and dissociation of a diatomic molecule. From these simple systems the theoretical ideas that are used to discuss the role of energy in chemical reactions are developed.

results.title: Chemical properties of water
results.brief_description: An explanation of the chemical properties of water in terms of the polar nature of the water molecule. Demonstrates chemical reactions of water with metals, metal oxides, non-metal oxides, and salts; shows how water, as a solvent, promotes other chemical reactions.
results.description: An explanation of the chemical properties of water in terms of the polar nature of the water molecule. Demonstrates chemical reactions of water with metals, metal oxides, non-metal oxides, and salts; shows how water, as a solvent, promotes other chemical reactions.

results.title: Chemical families
results.creator_credit: Davidson Films, David W. Ridgway and J. Arthur Campbell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Starting with a display of samples of over 70 elements, the film demonstrates methods by which chemical similarities among the elements have provided the basis for dividing them logically into families. By experiment and observation metals, non-metals, and the doubtful elements are grouped. The film demonstrates how atomic numbers have provided the key to the ordering of the elements in the periodic table.

results.title: Chemical evolution
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Bert Van Bork
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Origin of Life”.
Evidence supporting evolution of life in the primordial sea is the basis for the film’s content. Actual footage of scientific investigations is featured. These include: Russian biochemist - AI Oparin; Dr Stanley Miller and Dr Cyril Ponnamperuma. We also see a miniature amino acid analyser and other complex analytical apparatus at NASA’s Ames Research Centre.

results.title: Chemical equilibrium
results.creator_credit: Television Ontario, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and David Chamberlain
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: chemistry”.
These episodes examine the theory of steady state, dynamic equilibrium, kinetic molecular theory, reaction tendencies and the equilibrium constant. Illustrates forward and reverse reactions of various chemical changes including the production of hydrogen iodide, hydrogen chloride and ammonia. Finally, through demonstrations of Le Chatlier’s principle and the Haber process, students gain a better understanding of the importance of chemical equilibrium. The episodes are “Unsteady steadiness”, “Dynamic equilibrium”, Reaction kinetics”, “The Equilibrium constant” mand “The Haber process

results.title: Chemical engineering
results.creator_credit: Career Productions and Mutual Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Is this your career series”.
The chemical engineer applies engineering principles for chemical purposes, and works with the chemist and mechanical engineer. The design, erection and economical operation of chemical plants is his responsibility. He may have to analyse much data and prepare reports on plant operation. His grasp of maths must be strong and the computer is one of his tools. The university course indicates the wide field covered by his training.

results.title: Chemical conquest
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, David Bairstow and Larry Gosnell
results.brief_description: A film report on how chemical research is on the side of the farmer in battle against the plagues that threaten his crops. Insects, plant diseases and weeds come under close scrutiny as scientists develop new formulas to check the invasions to which field and garden crops are subject. The film shows laboratory experiments at a government research station and examines the questions that still need to be answered about the ultimate effects of toxic substances on food-producing soil. Narrated by James Tapp.

results.title: Chemical changes
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional and Beryl Denman Lacey
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Digestion”.
An account of the chief changes involved in the chemical breakdown of the main types of food during digestion. Shows the secretion of saliva and its action on cooked starch; the gastric glands; secretion of intestinal bile and pancreatic juice and their effect on proteins, carbohydrates and fats; the absorption of nutrients through the villi and lacteals into the blood and its subsequent circulation through the body.

results.title: Chemical bonding and atomic structure. - 2nd ed.
results.creator_credit: Don Lane Pictures, Coronet Films, Roger Mazur and Mel Waskin
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemistry”.
The substances forming our world are composed of atoms held together by powerful electrical forces called chemical bonds. The physical and chemical properties of elements and compounds depend on the nature of these bonds. Discusses metallic, ionic, covalent and interatomic bonds and forces dealing with ions, atoms, crystals, valence, polarity and Van der Waals forces. Suitable for upper secondary level.
